body: Changes look good except for some code that shouldn't have been removed.

Pull request has been merged.  Sorry for the delay. 

Thanks for your contribution!
Thanks!
This will require some work.  It appears RDFReader/RDFWriter have been replaced with different APIs.  It's not immediately obvious how to replace them with newer APIs.

@garydgregory - Are you still interested in implementing this?  I'm close to doing a preview release for 9.0.  It would be good to get this into 9.0.0.

Note that there have been changes to the way serializers are configured (no more properties like HTMLDOC_xxx and instead just builders now).  So unfortunately it's not a clean merge to get your current changes into the code.

Hi @jamesbognar 
In theory yes, but in practice I have my FOSS time pretty occupied ATM with Apache Commons, so I have to back away for now. I should be available for testing an RC to see if we have any compatibility issues with our product though.
Sounds good.  If you want, I can sort out the conflicts and merge the existing changes.  Otherwise I'll just leave this PR open for now?
@jamesbognar Feel free to merge or do as you best see fit. I apologize for not taking the time to dive back in ATM.
Looks like org.apache.jena:jena-core is no longer a dependency, so this is no longer needed.
LGTM!
LGTM!

For me, the build passes locally on Windows, these are odd permission failures. Hmm, are we really trying to read or write to the root folder? 
```
java.io.FileNotFoundException: /jetty-thread-dump-0.log (Permission denied)
```

I guess so:
```
try (FileWriter fw = new FileWriter(microservice.getConfig().get("Logging/logDir").orElse(".") + "/jetty-thread-dump-"+(dumpCount++)+".log")) {
```
I updated the above to not write to the root folder in this branch.

The next failures are a bunch of `Broken pipe (Write failed)` in `ThirdPartyProxyTest`. Interesting! Maybe GitHub does not allow what are we doing here... WDYT? I wonder if we can detect this and either not run the test or test differently...

My local build on Windows 10 is fine.
That should be writing to the working directory (./jetty-thread-dump-0.log), not the root directory.  Not sure why it's ending up in root.

> That should be writing to the working directory (./jetty-thread-dump-0.log), not the root directory. Not sure why it's ending up in root.

I fixed that in this branch.

Hi @jamesbognar,

Any thoughts on the broken pipe failures? Do you see this failure in a local build of this branch?
@garydgregory - I'll have to check out your branch and try it myself.  I won't be able to get to it today though.
Hi @jamesbognar Would you be able to check this branch soon?

I don't know why the maven build fails in GitHub.  I tested it locally and these changes were fine.  I merged your changes and the Jenkins build results were fine indicating that there isn't a regression: 
https://ci-builds.apache.org/blue/organizations/jenkins/Juneau%2FJuneau-Java-11/detail/Juneau-Java-11/755/pipeline

In this case the broken pipe is in the HTTP layer.  These tests should be running at most around 10 seconds.  It's really just HttpClient encountering a broken pipe trying to read from the servlet.  Something wonky is going on with the network layer in the build environment.  I'm curious to know if it's repeatable.  Only 22 of the 1000 tests actually failed.
Change merged.  Thanks!
This breaks javadoc generation.  Closing without merging.

See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MSHADE-462

Thank you,

I figured as much (the call to beanDictionary).  

The challenge I have is that I needed to parse library classes that I don't own, and can't change, and are not annotated.

When I attempted to use dynamic annotations (via the annotations() API methods) that didn't work. In other words, the  beanDictionary() and annotations() features do not compose.

I ended up having to implement a mixin like mechanism (similar to Jackson's) which modifies class and/or method level declared annotation metadata via reflection.  This is fragile since it depends on JDK implementation details, and also the semantics of the (default) annotations provider in Juneau (that loads the declared annotations).

To summarize. It seem parsing does not support polymorphic parsing with types that do not statically declared annotations.
Thanks again. I confirmed this is working.

FYI...there's a convenience method for this:
```
   WriterSerializer serializer = JsonSerializer
      .create()
      .typeName(MyBean.class, "mybean")
      .build();
```

https://juneau.apache.org/site/apidocs-9.0.0/org/apache/juneau/BeanContext.Builder.html#typeName(java.lang.Class,java.lang.String)
